The Heisenberg Paper

Peer-reviewed by no one who matters

On the Fundamental Impossibility of Perfect Carpet Cleaning: A Proof in Seven Stains

E. Vance & Q. [REDACTED] — Quantum Carpet Cleaning Research Division, 2025

Abstract: We present conclusive evidence that perfect carpet cleaning violates the Second Law of Thermodynamics, the Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle, and at least two of Eleanor's personal boundaries. Our findings suggest that the act of cleaning a carpet to perfection would require infinite energy, infinite time, and a level of emotional closure that neither author has achieved. [1]

Q wrote this part. I miss him.

Consider a carpet fiber of length l contaminated by a particle of diameter d. To remove this particle with certainty, one must know both its position and momentum simultaneously — a direct violation of ΔxΔp ≥ ℏ/2. The deeper you look, the less you can grasp. [3] We have found this principle applies equally to red wine, motor oil, and the question of why Q stopped returning calls in March. [7]

Furthermore, the entropy of a "clean" carpet is, by definition, lower than that of a "dirty" carpet. To decrease local entropy requires an equal or greater increase in entropy elsewhere. In our controlled trials, this manifested as: one broken vacuum, two existential crises, and the dissolution of a business partnership that was, for four years, the best thing in both our lives. [??]

We conclude that perfection in carpet cleaning is not merely impractical but physically forbidden. The universe prefers mess. It builds stars out of dust and expects us to be okay with that. [12]

[1] Vance, E. "Why I Started a Carpet Cleaning Company Instead of Finishing My PhD." Unpublished, 2023.

[3] The metaphor is load-bearing. Do not remove it.

[7] Q, if you're reading this: it was never about the carpet.

Frequently Asked Questions

We get asked these a lot. We answer them anyway.

Yes. Every cleaning event generates a branching timeline. In one universe, your carpet is pristine. In another, the stain won. In a third — our favorite — no one ever spilled anything because no one was brave enough to pour a glass of wine and sit on the floor with their best friend at 3am and say "What if we started a carpet cleaning company?"

The science is real. The application is absurd. Then again, most of the best things in life are technically absurd. Marriage is absurd. Friendship is absurd. Starting a business with someone because you both dropped out of physics and needed a reason to keep showing up somewhere every morning — that's the most absurd thing of all, and I'd do it again tomorrow.

It's stored in a secure quantum containment unit, which is a fancy way of saying a jar under the sink. Each jar is labeled with the date and a brief emotional profile of the stain. Q used to write little stories on the labels. One jar just says "Tuesday. Bad one." I can't throw it away.

We guarantee your carpet will be cleaner than it was. We do not guarantee satisfaction, because satisfaction is a temporary state that collapses upon examination. We do guarantee that we tried. We guarantee that someone knelt on your floor and cared about it for a little while. That has to count for something.
